Simple Moving Average Plot

Source: R/ts-sma-plot.R
ts_sma_plot.Rd

This function will take in a value column and return any number n moving averages.

ts_sma_plot(
  .data,
  .value_col,
  .sma_order,
  .centered = TRUE,
  .multi_plot = FALSE,
  .ionteractive = FALSE
)

Arguments

.data

The data that you are passing, this can be either a ts object or a tibble
.value_col

This only needs to be used if you are passing a tibble object.
.sma_order

This will default to 1. This can be a vector like c(2,4,6,12)
.multi_plot

This is a bool value of TRUE/FALSE, the default is FALSE. If this is set to TRUE, then all of the moving averages will be put on the plot.
.date_col

This only needs to be used if you are passing a tibble object.
.alignment

This can be either "left", "center", "right"
.partial

This is a bool value of TRUE/FALSE, the default is TRUE
.interactive

This is a bool value of TRUE/FALSE, the default is FALSE. If this is set to TRUE, then a plotly::ggplotly object will be returned.

Value

Will invisibly return a list object.

Details

This function will accept a time series object or a tibble/data.frame. This is a simple wrapper around timetk::slidify_vec(). It uses that function to do the underlying moving average work.

It can only handle a single moving average at a time and therefore if multiple are called for, it will loop through and append data to a tibble or ts object.

Author

Steven P. Sanderson II, MPH

Developed by Steven Sanderson.
